G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Such modification is necessary to ensure the health, safety, and best interests of Emily Ramirez and Noah Ramirez, as articulated under G.L. c. 208, �������������������������������������������������������������������������������.

_Ardizoni v. Raymond_, 40 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody orders may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where such changes impact the best interests of the children. See G.L. c. 208, ���������������������������������; _Ardizoni v. Raymond_, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 736 (1996).
_Ardizoni v. Raymond_, 40 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly cites and applies G.L. c. 208, § 28, stating that a Probate Court judge may modify an earlier custody judgment upon finding a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court then applies this standard to determine whether the wife’s complaint for modification was properly allowed, thus directly supporting the proposition about Massachusetts law on modification of custody orders.
_Ardizoni v. Raymond_, 40 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’”

_Rosenthal v. Maney_, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The presence of a third party known to have a criminal history and a pattern of domestic violence within the Defendants household constitutes a significant change in circumstances that justifies modification.
_Rosenthal v. Maney_, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any third party with a criminal history or a pattern of domestic violence residing in the custodial parent’s household, nor does it treat such a circumstance as a basis for modification. Instead, the case holds that a change of custody must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the custodial parent’s relocation, and finds no such change here. Thus, it provides no authority for the proposition that the presence of a violent third party in the home constitutes a significant change justifying modification.
_Rosenthal v. Maney_, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements…”

_Mason v. Coleman_, 447 Mass. 177, 184-8.proposition: The presence of a third party known to have a criminal history and a pattern of domestic violence within the Defendants household constitutes a significant change in circumstances that justifies modification.
_Mason v. Coleman_, 447 Mass. 177, 184-8.support_reasoning: The case concerns standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth in a joint physical custody situation and the general ‘best interests’ analysis for relocation. It does not address modification of custody or parenting time based on the presence of a third party with a criminal history or a pattern of domestic violence in the household. The only third-party misconduct discussed is an allegation of inappropriate touching by a step-sibling, which is treated as one factor in a best-interests removal analysis, not as a ‘significant change in circumstances’ justifying modification.
_Mason v. Coleman_, 447 Mass. 177, 184-8.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Chelmsford schools were preferable to those of Bristol, particularly for the child with special needs; that uprooting the children would be detrimental to their interests; that the move would cause a reduction of the father’s parenting time that would not be in the children’s interests; that misconduct allegations against a step-sibling weighed against increased time in the mother’s household; and that there was insufficient evidence of financial imperative to justify the mother’s move to Bristol.”

_Hale v. Hale_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.proposition: The Court has recognized that where a childs safety and welfare are at risk, immediate and necessary modifications are warranted.
_Hale v. Hale_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for permitting removal of children from the Commonwealth and the need to consider the custodial parent’s well-being when assessing the children’s best interests. It does not discuss emergency, immediate, or expedited modifications prompted by threats to a child’s safety or welfare. The court reverses a prohibition on removal for lack of adequate best‑interest findings, not because immediate modifications were warranted to protect child safety.
_Hale v. Hale_, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice….”

_Schechter v. Schechter_, 88 Mass. App..proposition: The Court has recognized that where a childs safety and welfare are at risk, immediate and necessary modifications are warranted.
_Schechter v. Schechter_, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that the child’s welfare and safety are paramount and affirms a one‑year total suspension of the father’s contact with the child, including embedding that no‑contact provision in a permanent abuse‑prevention (209A) order. The court explains that, given the documented pattern and serious incident of abuse and the emotional harm further contact would cause, such restrictive and immediate measures are warranted to protect the child’s best interests and safety. This aligns with the proposition that when a child’s safety and welfare are at risk, necessary modifications to custody/visitation should be ordered.
_Schechter v. Schechter_, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: We recognize that “parents have a fundamental interest in their relationships with their children that is constitutionally protected.” ... [T]he strong expression of public policy by our Legislature that a child’s welfare must be the paramount concern when a judge determines custody ... means that a judge is authorized not only to order sole legal and physical custody with one parent when it serves the best interests of the child ... but also that a judge is authorized to impose conditions and restrictions on and to suspend any visitation by the other parent when it is determined that visitation would not be in the best interests of the child.

_Furtado v. Furtado_, 380 Mass. 137, 144.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have also emphasized that exposure to domestic violence or disruptive conditions can warrant supervised visitation to protect the children.
_Furtado v. Furtado_, 380 Mass. 137, 144.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal contempt for failure to pay child support and the procedural distinctions between civil and criminal contempt in that context. It does not discuss visitation, supervised visitation, domestic violence, or disruptive home conditions as factors in custody or parenting-time determinations. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts use exposure to domestic violence or disruptive conditions as a basis for ordering supervised visitation.
_Furtado v. Furtado_, 380 Mass. 137, 144.relevant_excerpt: "A contempt proceeding for failure to comply with a support order may be brought as a civil contempt proceeding, as a criminal contempt proceeding, or as both a criminal and a civil contempt proceeding.... In a criminal contempt proceeding involving an alleged failure to comply with an order to pay certain amounts for the support of a wife or a minor child, or both, one area of possible difficulty concerns the defendant’s ability to pay."

_Humes v. Humes_, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 129,.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have also emphasized that exposure to domestic violence or disruptive conditions can warrant supervised visitation to protect the children.
_Humes v. Humes_, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 129,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the sufficiency of grand jury evidence to support indictments for involuntary manslaughter and illegal possession of a hypodermic needle in a heroin-overdose case. It does not involve family law, child custody, visitation, or domestic violence, nor does it discuss supervised visitation or protecting children from exposure to disruptive conditions. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts courts and supervised visitation in the context of domestic violence.
_Humes v. Humes_, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 129,.relevant_excerpt: “The Commonwealth appeals, claiming that the judge erred in finding that there was ‘not sufficient evidence that the defendant engaged in wanton or reckless conduct and thereby caused the death of the victim.’ We agree with the Commonwealth’s contention… [T]here was sufficient evidence to support an indictment for involuntary manslaughter based on the defendant’s distribution of the drug to Moscuzza.”

_Adoption of Hugo_, 428 Mass. 219, 231 (.proposition: The Plaintiff asserts that the requested modification is narrowly tailored and reasonable in light of the circumstances and is consistent with the principle that the children's best interests and safety are paramount. See _Adoption of Hugo_, 428 Mass. 219, 231 (1998); G.L. c. 208, ���������������������������������.
_Adoption of Hugo_, 428 Mass. 219, 231 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is an adoption/custody case focused entirely on the best-interests-of-the-child standard and the trial judge’s discretion in weighing competing adoption plans. It does not discuss, apply, or articulate any standard about a party’s requested modification being “narrowly tailored and reasonable,” nor does it frame any relief in those terms. While it certainly affirms that the child’s best interests are paramount, it does not provide authority for the specific ‘narrow tailoring and reasonableness’ characterization used in the proposition, so the citation overstates what Hugo supports.
_Adoption of Hugo_, 428 Mass. 219, 231 (.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’… it is for the trial judge to determine the weight of the evidence; we do not require that any evidence be established with exceptional force.”
